contentrichtext.text: In [[human anatomy]], the '''quadriceps tendon''' connects the [[Quadriceps muscle|quadriceps femoris]] muscles to the superior aspects of the [[patella]] on the anterior of the thigh and controls knee flexion and extension. It can rupture resulting in [[quadriceps tendon rupture]].<ref name="pmid17394710">{{Cite journal |author=Jolles BM, Garofalo R, Gillain L, Schizas C |title=A new clinical test in diagnosing quadriceps tendon rupture |journal=Ann R Coll Surg Engl |volume=89 |issue=3 |pages=259–61 |year=2007 |month=April |pmid=17394710 |pmc=1964733 |doi=10.1308/003588407X179044 |url=http://openurl.ingenta.com/content/nlm?genre=article&issn=0035-8843&volume=89&issue=3&spage=259&aulast=Jolles}}</ref> It has been studied in the analysis of [[patellofemoral pain syndrome]].<ref name="pmid19541742">{{Cite journal |author=Wilson NA, Press JM, Zhang LQ |title=In vivo strain of the medial vs. lateral quadriceps tendon in patellofemoral pain syndrome |journal=J. Appl. Physiol. |volume=107 |issue=2 |pages=422–8 |year=2009 |month=August |pmid=19541742 |doi=10.1152/japplphysiol.00024.2009 |url=http://jap.physiology.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=19541742}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Muscles of lower limb}} {{Musculoskeletal-stub}} [[Category:Tendons]]
